Award.AbstractNarration:
The American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) and the National Science Foundation (NSF) will continue its collaboration in providing early and mid-career scientists and engineers with opportunities for professional development and public service via the AAAS Science and Technology Fellowship Program. Annually, Fellows will be selected competitively and placed in offices throughout NSF, working on projects of mutual interest to the Fellow and the host directorate or office. By providing insight into the decision-making process, and learning about current issues affecting the scientific and engineering enterprise, Fellows will discover how NSF funds science, while providing scientific, engineering and educational input on issues relating to NSF's mission support of basic science and engineering research and education.

Fellows will work with staff involved in planning, development and oversight of agency programs in all fields of fundamental research. Assignments may involve significant interagency, congressional or international activity, as well as involvement with the National Science Board, NSF's policy-setting body. The program includes an orientation on executive branch and congressional operations, as well as a yearlong seminar program on matters involving science, technology and public policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The AAAS Science & Technology Policy Fellowships provide a program of public service and professional development that enables competitively selected scientists and engineers to learn first-hand about the use of science and technology in the federal government decision making, policies and programs, while offering valuable contributions of their knowledge and analytical skills to federal agencies and offices.

Since 1973, AAAS has trained 41 classes of S&T Policy Fellows, placing approximately 1,700 scientists and engineers in the executive branch at nearly 20 federal agencies, and more than 1,200 Fellows in Congress. Fellows' feedback attests that the experience enhances their capacity to engage more effectively on a broad spectrum of issues with a wide range of audiences.

The program also has profoundly influenced fellows' careers. Many transition into policy positions at the local, state, regional, federal and international levels. Some apply their new policy skills in the non-profit and private sectors. Others return to academia where they teach and mentor new generations of scientists to understand the policy context of research and the importance of communicating science to non-scientific stakeholders. Many AAAS Fellows who have returned to academia report that their research is now more focused on addressing policy challenges.


They all carry with them an understanding of U.S. government programs and initiatives; the many factors affecting policy; and the critical importance of research, applied science, and outreach that address social, economic and environmental challenges, support public policy, and contribute to the wellbeing of the nation and citizens around the world.


AAAS Fellows hosted by executive agencies learn how federal agencies affect national policy and how federal agencies interact with the legislative branch, as well as how a federal agency develops and communicates its mission and how independent it can be in its actions.

 

At NSF, fellows had the opportunity to experience and participate in many aspects of the Foundation's activities, including how it determines its course of action regarding policy, regulation, research and education, how external agendas (from the White House or from Congress) affect it, how disciplinary
directorates are linked with other parts of NSF, and how those links contribute
to the Foundation's mission. The Fellows at NSF gained insight into how and by whom national science and technology policy is driven, shaped and prioritized, and they learned how national science and technology goals are translated into and reflected by NSF's mission and strategic goals. They also gained a greater understanding of NSF missions, strategies, structure, policies and culture.
